Well, I disagree because I disagree with your definition of user: the main "user" of this site is the modder, not the mod user, and it does a pretty good job at it.

If you check the issues you will see that most of the feature requests are meant for the modder, not for the mod user.

@SirCmpwn: it looks like the download per version graph is a bit flawed:

(this is for my low profile misc engines set).

@Ippo: of course but restricting by some means the users base of KS is a bad thing and IMHO a "modders only" website is mostly useless.

(many hosting sites provide the same important features like download statistics and obviously hosting, it just need more work on display from modders)

Thanks for the tip, Justin.

As for whether or not Kerbal Stuff is a site for modders or for mod users, the answer is both. However, the important one is modders, since users will go where the modders go. I wanted to cater to them first and now I can cater to the users. Like I keep saying, it's in beta and some things are definitely lacking.

Redesign update: I fixed all the links (so it'll always be /mod/id/name instead of /mod/id) and did a bunch of tweaking. The biggest accomplishment of the past few hours, though, is that I redid the mod creation process:

https://mediacru.sh/9z0z0tC6jYHd

That complicated form is gone and now it's just the bare minimum. You can add detail after your mod is created. The result is that it takes less than a minute to upload a new mod

After doing some marathon coding today, the redesign is finished! You can check it out now, it's live: http://beta.kerbalstuff.com

There are a number of todo items I closed with this redesign. Among them are the ability to browse every mod on the site, and a bunch of bug fixes.

And thanks again to Chris Burns for the design inspiration and a lot of the CSS work! It looks great.
